title-group.article-title: Coupled squeeze film analysis by Reissner–Mindlin plate elements

article-meta.aff: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Michigan Technological University, USA

author-notes.corresp: MM Altuğ Bιçak, Department of Mechanical Engineering – Engineering Mechanics, Michigan Technological University, 1400 Townsend Drive Houghton, MI, 49931-1295, USA Email: mmbicak@mtu.edu

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Squeeze film damping effects naturally occur if structures are subjected to loading situations such that a very thin film of fluid is trapped within structural joints, interfaces, etc. An accurate estimate of squeeze film effects is important to predict the performance of dynamic structures. This paper presents a finite element solution to the coupled fluid–structure problem of squeeze film dampers. The squeeze film is governed by the linearized isothermal Reynolds equation, which is known from lubrication theory. The structure which is modeled using Reissner–Mindlin plate theory is discretized by four-noded two-dimensional shear deformable isoparametric plate elements. The coupled finite element formulation is derived and an alternative solution to obtain damped eigenvalues and eigenvectors is presented. The coupling between fluid and structure is handled by considering the pressure forces and structural surface velocities on the boundaries. The effects of the driving parameters on the frequency response functions are investigated. It was found that the ambient pressure has no significant effect on the frequency responses, unlike on the damping force of dynamical MEMS systems. The results obtained from the presented model are compared with the experimental and analytical results available in the literature and a very good agreement is found.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Squeeze film damping behaviors are widely observed in many applications such as machine tools, bearings, gears, automotive engines, rolling elements, hydraulic systems, computer hard disks, and skeletal joints. Squeeze film dampers (SFDs) are frequently used for vibration control and the stabilization of high speed rotating machines such as gas turbine engines and turbochargers, and they have a significant influence on the dynamic performance of the systems (Gross, 1962; Bhushan, 1999; Bao, 2000). Many investigations deal with the SFD described by the wave equation as seen in Tijdeman (1975), Fox and Whitton (1980), Trochidis (1982), Chow and Pinnington (1987), Onsay (1994), and Beltman et al. (1998).

Squeeze film damping can be modeled using the Reynolds equation, which is derived from the Navier–Stokes equations and the continuity equation. The main assumption is that the gas in the gap can be treated as a continuum. The resistive and damping force to the structure oscillating normally against the stationary base structure is caused by the pressure distribution of the fluid film. Generally, if the structure oscillates with a low frequency, the fluid is not compressed considerably. In this case, there might be additional mass loading due to the air pumping mechanism. However, if the speed of the structure is high, the air fails to escape, resulting in elastic force domination. The Reynolds equation is not valid for high frequencies since the Reynolds equation does not include inertial terms. The measure of applicability of the Reynolds equation for high frequencies can be found by comparing inertial forces with viscous forces. Gross (1962) defined the validity of the Reynolds equation by using the modified Reynolds number Re*, which is defined by the ratio of the inertial force to the viscous force. According to this approach, the Reynolds equation is valid for Re* << 1 since the Poiseuille velocity profile along the gap is assumed. The other important factor is the Knudsen number, which is the ratio of the molecular mean free path of the gas to the fluid film thickness. The molecular mean free path is the distance that a gas particle travels between collisions. The Knudsen number shows the applicability of the Reynolds equation. Under a typical ambient pressure of 101 kPa, the mean free path of the air is 65 nm, which implies a minimum film thickness of 0.01 mm in order to apply Reynolds equation.

This paper investigates the dynamic responses of SFDs for flat surfaces considering coupled fluid–structure behavior. The isothermal Reynolds equation known from lubrication theory represents the fluid film behavior. The Reissner–Mindlin plate structure is modeled using four-noded two-dimensional shear deformable isoparametric finite elements. The derivation of finite elements for both structural and fluid domains is presented. Using the fluid film pressures and the structure velocities on the boundary as the boundary coupling terms, the damped natural frequencies with damping ratios are predicted with the aid of the coupled finite model, and are compared with both the measurements and analytical results available in the literature. Additionally, frequency response functions are calculated to show the effect of fluid film thickness variation on the dynamic behavior of the structure. Moreover, the finite element matrix formulation for partial coverage SFDs is derived and the determination of the optimal connection points is discussed.

sec.title: 2. Mathematical formulation
sec.p:
Squeeze film analysis in elastic plates is carried out considering elastic motion of the bounded plates. A typical plate–squeeze-film system is presented in Figure 1. The base of the plate is treated as rigid. The fluid film pressure underneath the plate changes due to the surface oscillation of the plate causing fluid to be squeezed or sucked, which in turn alters the plate oscillations and fluid film forces on the plate. The two way interaction forces are shown in Figure 2. In the present analysis the fluid is characterized by a single pressure variable and the coupling is achieved through a consideration of the interface forces. This method is widely used and has the advantage that, in general, a much smaller number of variables are used to describe the fluid behavior. Figure 1.
Plate and squeeze film fluid domain. Figure 2.
Coupled field with forces.

sec.title: 2.1. Structure domain: the Reissner–Mindlin model
sec.p: Reissner–Mindlin plate theory is used to model the structure domain which includes both bending and transverse shear deformations. The kinetic and potential energy expressions for a plate element are (1) (2) with (3) in which (4) the constitutive equation for the plane stress and shear, where Ωse is the element's structure domain, u is the transversal displacement of the plate, θx and θy are the rotations around x and y axis respectively, ρ is the mass density per unit area, E is Young's modulus, v is Poisson's ratio, ht is the plate thickness, and κ is the shear energy correction factor which is taken as 5/6.

The plate is discretized using four-noded isoparametric quadrilateral plate elements with transverse and rotational deformations as shown in Figure 3. The element has 12 degrees of freedom (DOF), i.e. one displacement u and two rotations, θx and θy, at each node. The displacement and structural rotations within an element are approximated using their nodal values as given by (5) where Ni represents the shape functions associated with ith node and defined as follows: (6) Now, the nodal degrees of freedom are (7) where T denotes the matrix transpose. Figure 3.
Plate element geometry coupled with pressure field.
The consistent element mass matrix for the plate element can then be written as (8) where Ωse represents the domain of the element and N is defined as follows: (9)

Assuming a linear elastic material with the stress–strain relation σ = Dbϵ and a strain–displacement relation ϵ = Bd, the elemental bending stiffness matrix can be obtained from the following relation: (10) where B and Bs represent the differentiations of the shape function N, as indicated in Equation (3). More information on the derivation of the element matrices can be found in Hughes et al. (1977). The calculation of derivatives wrt physical coordinates requires that a Jacobian matrix J be calculated as shown: (11)
The numerical integration is straightforward and handled using 2 × 2 Gauss–Legendre quadrature for bending and 1 × 1 for shear.

The finite element semi-discretized equation for the dynamics of the plate structure can now be written in the familiar form given below. No damping is considered in the motion of the plate. (12) where K, M are the globally assembled stiffness and mass matrices respectively, and u is the displacement vector. A superposed double dot represents the second time derivative. The fluid-film–structure coupling is represented by the term QTp, where p is the vector of the fluid film pressure. The element-wise version of the coupling matrix Q is given by (13) where the shape functions for the structure and fluid domains are represented by N and Nf respectively.

sec.title: 2.2. Fluid domain
sec.p:
The Reynolds equation is applicable only in the continuum flow regime; the relationship between the Knudsen number and flow regimes is shown in Table 1. Table 1.
Knudsen number and the corresponding flow regimes
Knudsen number (Kn) Flow Regime
Kn < 0.01 Continuum
0.01 < Kn < 0.1 Slip
0.1 <Kn < 10 Transitional
Kn > 10 Molecular

Considering P = Pa + p and h = h0 + u, where u is the plate displacement and h0 is the film thickness, the following linear version of the Reynolds equation for the fluid domain Ωf can be rewritten under the assumptions of
plate displacement is small compared to the film thickness; and
pressure variation is small compared to the ambient pressure: (16)

The fluid film is discretized using four-noded quadrilateral elements as shown in the Figure 3. The element has only four DOF, i.e. pressure p at each node. The pressure within an element is approximated using the nodal values as given by (17) where Nfi represents the shape functions associated with ith node and defined as in Equation (6).
Now, the nodal degrees of freedom are (18)

Using weak formulation and introducing the finite element approximations, Equation (16) reduces to the following equation: (19) where Mf and Kf are, respectively, the assembled global mass and stiffness matrices for the fluid. A superposed dot represents the time derivative. The element-wise mass and stiffness matrices can be obtained from the following relations: (20) (21)
The coupling matrix Qf transfers the velocities of the structure to the fluid domain and can be obtained by globally assembling the following element-wise coupling matrix Qfe: (22)

sec.title: 2.3. Applicability of Reynolds equation
sec.p: In 1962, Langlois (Langlois, 1962) derived the general form of the Reynolds equation based on the Navier–Stokes equations and the general equations of hydrodynamics. The Reynolds equation is obtained under the condition that the modified Reynolds number is much smaller than unity. The Reynolds equation is not valid for high frequencies since it does not include inertial terms. The measure of applicability of the Reynolds equation can be found by comparing inertial forces with viscous forces per volume (Gross, 1962): (23) where u is the fluid flow velocity in the direction of n. Assuming the Poiseuille velocity profile along the gap and the direction n as the x axis, the following formula can be obtained for the fluid flow velocity: (24) where z is the direction along the gap. The modified Reynolds number is defined as (25) which should be smaller than unity for any point underneath the plate. The modified Reynolds number can be rewritten using the squeeze number as (26) where σ is the squeeze number per unit area, (27) The modified Reynolds number formula considering the journal bearings can be found in Gross (1962).

sec.title: 3. Solution of the problem
sec.p: Equations (12) and (19) can be combined to obtain the complete fluid–structure dynamic interaction equation as follows: (28) where I and 0 represent the identity and zero matrices with appropriate sizes respectively. The above equation can be rewritten in a compact form as (29)

The solution and implementation of the above non-standard unsymmetric system needs considerably larger core storage, since the matrices in the second term of Equation (29) are denser matrices, unlike the original banded mass and stiffness matrices. The generalized eigenvalue problem to determine the nontrivial solutions of Equation (29) is given by introducing (30) as follows: (31)

The solution of the above generalized eigenvalue problem is straightforward and can be handled using standard numerical techniques. However, one of the main disadvantages of this approach is the rearrangement of the matrices to form KG and MG, which also causes a longer solution time due to complex eigenvalues. To overcome this issue, the following simple method is proposed. Assuming harmonic motion of angular frequency ω, the structure displacements and fluid pressures can be expressed as (32) Equation (28) can be rewritten as follows: (33) Substituting the above equation into Equation (12) results in (34)

The above equation, on pre- and post-multiplication with φi T and ϕi, can be rewritten in the following form: (35) or in compact form as Au0 = 0 where ωi and ϕi are the ith natural frequency and the mass normalized eigenvector of the following pure structural equation: (36)

The nontrivial solutions of Equation (35) can be found by investigating the roots of det(A) = 0, which can be solved by using the iterative conjugate gradient method for ω. Then the corresponding damped eigenvector can be found by putting the complex natural frequency solution into Equation (35). Once the damped eigenvector is obtained the pressure distribution can be calculated using Equation (33) by replacing ω and u0 with the calculated damped eigenvalue and eigenvector solution.
The frequency response function of the coupled system for a particular harmonically varying external force fext can be obtained using Equation (34), as (37)

sec.title: 3.1. Two plate case
sec.p: The vibration and noise of an oscillating surface can be suppressed by adding another plate to create a fluid film between two plates. This also enables blocking of sound and provides extra noise suppression. However, the pumping fluid motion inside the film may create high frequency noise. Addition of the SFD to the main structure can be modeled using the previous approach as shown below: (38) where ub is the base structural displacement vector, Mb and Kb are the mass and stiffness matrices of the base structure, and Qb and Qbf are the coupling matrices between the base structure and the fluid film. It is important to note that an additional term is added to the fluid film equation due to differences between base structure and SFD velocities. The above equation implies that the base and SFD vibrations can be suppressed using a single fluid film. Enhancement of the vibration damping is directly related to the difference between velocities of oscillating surfaces.

The coupling matrices Qf and Qbf are the same matrices when the base structure is modeled using the same shape functions as in the SFD model, since the base and the SFD share identical boundaries with the fluid film. In the particular case where the base and SFD possess the same velocity magnitudes and directions, the fluid domain coupling terms cancel each other and the fluid film domain provides no extra damping or stiffness to the plates.

sec.title: 4. Results and discussion
sec.p: In this section, some specific results for finite element method computations of fluid–structure interaction are given using the formulation described in this paper. To illustrate the fluid–structure behavior, a simple 2 DOF coupled system which has the following matrices is hypothetically selected: (39)

The effects of the fluid film thickness, the ambient pressure and viscosity are shown in Figure 4. The effect of film thickness on receptance is obtained with various film thickness values starting from 10−2 m to 10−5 m. The damping levels, as expected, are enhanced due to a decrease in gap thickness and increased viscosities. The ambient pressure change (Pa = 100 Pa – 1 MPa) doesn't provide any extra damping. Figure 4.
Effect of the film thickness (a), the ambient pressure (b), the fluid viscosity (c).

Next, a rectangular plate–fluid system is considered for the verification study. The plate is 49 cm wide, 24.5 cm in height, with a thickness of 1 mm. The plate is clamped at the edges. The box is made of aluminum, and the material properties are: (40)
The properties of the air in the gap under standard atmospheric conditions are: (41)

A Matlab (Matlab, 2003) script was developed to obtain the finite element matrices and results. The damped eigenfrequencies of the plate were calculated with a mesh of 514 plate elements and compared both with measurement results obtained by Beltman et al. (Beltman et al., 1998) and analytical results according to the formula given by Blevins (Blevins, 1995) in vacuum. The results are shown in Table 2. In this table, the first column represents the number of half-wavelengths in the x and y directions. Table 2.
Eigenfrequencies (Hz) of a rectangular clamped plate on an air film
Mode Analytical (Blevins, 1995) Measurement (Beltman et al., 1998) Present study
1,1 100.6 96.2 96.36
2,1 130.4 130.1 130.2
3,1 183.4 181.8 182.9
4,1 259.7 253.8 255.4
1,2 261.7 247.4 257.1
2,2 291.2 280.8 284.3
3,2 341.0 322.6 335.2

The results obtained by using the present approach are slightly lower than the analytical results due to mass loading of the fluid. Due to Bellman's observations, there is moderate agreement between the calculations and the experiments. The results tend to be less accurate due to the small number of elements for the higher modes.

A rectangular aluminum plate which has dimensions of 10 cm × 6 cm × 1 mm was selected as the second example. One of the shorter edges of the plate was clamped and all the other edges were free and open to ambient pressure. The shifts in the eigenvalues and damping ratios are listed in Table 3. Table 3.
Natural frequencies (Hz) and damping ratios of clamped-free-free-free rectangular plate for various fluid film thicknesses
Vacuum Present study (Hz)
Mode (Hz) h0 = 0.5 mm h0 = 1 mm h0 = 2 mm h0 = 5 mm
1 84.47 85.27 ζ = 14.9% 84.54 ζ = 1.96% 84.48 ζ = 0.24% 84.47
2 311.5 311.5 ζ = 0.23% 311.5 ζ = 0.03% 311.5 ζ = 0.00% 311.5
3 526.8 525.9 ζ = 3.73% 526.3 ζ = 0.46% 526.7 ζ = 0.06% 526.8
4 1038.2 1038.1 ζ = 0.41% 1038.2 ζ = 0.05% 1038.2 ζ = 0.00% 1038.2
5 1461.5 1462.2 ζ = 1.21% 1461.6 ζ = 0.14% 1461.5 ζ = 0.02% 1461.5

Comparing the calculated eigenfrequency shifts against the undamped natural frequency results, the sensitivities of the second and fourth modes to the gap thickness change are less than the others. This is due to the difference between the mass loading effects.

An aluminum 1 cm thick rectangular plate which was pinned from the bottom corners was selected as the third example. The dimensions of the plate were 25 cm by 15 cm. The frequency response function was calculated, and is shown in Figure 5 to emphasize the effect of film thickness on the dynamic behavior of the structure. Figure 5.
Frequency response function.

The shifts of the structural natural frequencies are dependent on the fluid film thickness, as expected. Interestingly, the effect is not uniform and dependent upon the mode shape of the structure. The first and fourth receptance peak regions show that the amount of damping and shift is different for each case.

sec.title: 4.1. Partial coverage air SFD
sec.p: Partial coverage air film dampers possess practical importance for controlling vibration. A first step in the process of developing an accurate model is to use the finite element approach defined by Equation (38). The dynamic behavior of the entire system is dependent not only on film thickness, and the material properties of the plates, but also on the connection locations of the attached air film damper to the main vibrating structure. The general rule for identifying possible connection locations is to select the best locations that maximize the total surface velocity profile acting on the fluid domain.

sec.title: 5. Conclusion
sec.p: In this paper the effects of squeeze film damping for structures which undergo transversal motion have been investigated. A finite element model for two-dimensional Reissner–Mindlin plate theory coupled with the isothermal Reynolds equation was developed. The two way coupling is provided using boundary forces, and structural velocities on the boundary. The derivation of a numerical model using four-noded isoparametric finite elements which is capable of modeling both structural and fluid domain is presented. An alternative solution method to the calculation of coupled eigenvalues and eigenvectors is also demonstrated.

The effects of fluid film thickness, ambient pressure, and fluid viscosity on the frequency response function are investigated using given examples and it has been shown that the influence of the fluid film thickness on the damping is dependent upon the structural mode shape. It is observed that the ambient pressure has no significant effect on the frequency responses, whereas it is an important factor on the damping force of MEMS systems. The finite element matrix formulation for the partial coverage SFDs is derived, and the determination of the optimal connection point locations for partial coverage SFDs is discussed.

sec.title: Conflict of interest
sec.p: None declared.
